EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

The following Risk Management Plan has been prepared for the Maple Leaf Bakery (Maple Leaf) facility located at 1955 Blue Hills Road NE in Roanoke, Virginia (see Figure 1).  This facility is a commercial bakery, which operates a single ammonia system to cool bread products prior to distribution and chill glycol for cooling mixing equipment.  This program has been prepared pursuant to Part 68, Subpart G of Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations.

The system contains approximately 20,000 pounds of ammonia.  The maximum quantity of ammonia contained on site is approximately 20,000 pounds.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

To prevent the accidental release of ammonia, Maple Leaf has developed the following: 

- 	Maintenance procedures to ensure that equipment is properly maintained and functioning properly.
-	Operating procedures to ensure that equipment is operated in a manner that minimizes the possibility of an ammonia release.
- 	Employee training to ensure that operators know how to properly use the equipment and non-operators are aware of the dangers of ammonia and the necessary steps to take in the event of an ammonia release.

The programs are contained in Binder 4: Ammonia Operating Procedures.

The general emergency response policy for the site when ammonia is released is to evacuate to an area upwind of the release and notify the appropriate personnel and authorities.  Trained personnel will then assess whether to evacuate the facility, and determine the appropriate level of response.  A copy of the Emergency Response Plan for Maple Leaf can be found in Binder 3.  A description of the ERP is contained in Section 6.0 Emergency Response Program in this document.

Stationary Source and Substance Handled

As explained above, Maple Leaf operates a single ammonia cooling system to cool and/or freeze bread products prior to shipment, and to chill glycol for on site material mixing.

The Worst Case Scenario (WC), atmospheric release of the maximum contents of the largest high pressure vessel (HPR-1) in 10 minutes, which is based upon 40 CFR, Section 68.25 criteria, is considered improbable.

Alternate Scenario 1 (A1) is a release of high pressure ammonia vapor originating from the low pressure accumulator that is released in the high stage compressor after compression.  This was done to simulate a compressor seal failure, which was identified as the most common mode of failure in this type of ammonia system that could result in a release.

In order to reduce the distance to the endpoint from an accidental release, the following administrative controls and mitigation measures are in place at Maple Leaf:

- 	Regular maintenance on the equipment.
- 	Daily inspections of equipment.
- 	Computer monitoring system.

Details regarding the offsite consequence analysis for the worst case and alternative release scenarios can be found in Section 3.0 of this document.

 General Accidental Release Prevention Program Components and Substance Specific Prevention Steps

The following components are contained in the following sections of this Risk Management Plan document:

- 	Registration
- 	Offsite Consequence Analysis
- 	Five-year Accident History
- 	Program Specific Component
- 	Emergency Response Program

In order to further mitigate the effects of a ammonia release, the following risk management components are in place:

- 	Main

tenance and standard operating procedures for the ammonia systems.
- 	Emergency Response Plan.
- 	Training for employees.
- 	Incident investigation documentation and procedures.
- 	Automatic system shutdowns.
- 	Windsocks for direction of wind visible on property.

Five-year Accident History

Maple Leaf has had no incidents in the past five years from the ammonia system that meet the criteria set forth in 40 CFR, Section 68.42.

Emergency Response Plan Components

The Emergency Response Plan (ERP) for the Maple Leaf facility has been prepared (see Binder 3) and contains information for responding to an ammonia release.  The general emergency response policy for the site when ammonia is released is to evacuate to an area upwind of the release and notify the appropriate personnel and authorities.  Trained personnel will then assess whether to evacuate the facility, and determine the appropriate level of response.

 Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Based on the results of the Process Hazard Analysis, the following recommendations have been made to improve safety at the facility:


#
Recommendations
Completion Date


1
Store hazardous materials (i.e. oil on pallets in the compressor room) in a different location to minimize employee traffic into and out of the compressor room.



2
Keep slave computer control panel closed and locked when not in use. This will help prevent disgruntled employees and vandals from operating the solenoid switches that are designed to prevent material releases.



3
Update the ammonia system inspection procedures. The equipment in the compressor room should be checked at least once per shift, preferably two (2) or three (3) times per shift (every two or three hours). In addition, the ammonia equipment located on the roof should be visually inspected at least once per day. There are no sensors on the roof, thus if routine visual inspections are not performed regularly, a small ammonia leak could exist for

an extended period of time before it is detected. 

Rooftop inspection procedures should include a step where the inspector checks in with somebody prior to and after going onto the roof.  This will help ensure the safety of the person performing the rooftop inspection.



4
Evaluate improving the security of the compressor room. This may be accomplished either by changing the locks on the doors to the compressor room to account for personnel changes or by installing a keypad system.



5
Ensure P&ID is updated to reflect actual facility construction (remove the HSD line to LT-1 and move bleed-off valves to side of rooftop piping).



6
Test the ammonia sensors at least every year to ensure they are functioning properly and replace them per manufacturer recommendation.



7
Ensure evacuation drills are performed at least once per year.



8
Label the King Valve on the High Pressure Receiver.



9
Lock the hatch to the roof when not in use. This will prevent unauthorized personnel from being on the roof and tampering with ammonia equipment. 



10
Ensure that the sight glass on the high pressure receiver is properly installed and operating.



11
Obtain SCBA equipment to respond to minor emergencies at the facility.



12
Install a display panel outside the ammonia room so employees will know the ammonia concentration in the room before entering.



13
Consider installing a charged water hose in compressor room.



14
Consider the use of wind direction arrows instead of windsock.
